abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Mineral Resources
            Governance Project for Madagascar were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was high, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. There were two lessons learned: 1)
            High-level scientific oversight is key to ensuring the
            success of a complex geology program. 2) A multi-stakeholder
            approach is critical to promoting good governance of mineral resources.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Mineral Resources Governance
            Project : Additional Financing

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Paper seeks the approval of
            the Executive Directors to provide an additional credit to
            the Republic of Madagascar for the Mineral Resources
            Governance Project. The additional credit will help finance
            the costs associated with scaled-up activities to enhance
            the impact of a well-performing project and meet the
            Government of Madagascar's demands for assistance in
            sustainable development and transparent management of the
            extractive industries. The additional financing credit fully
            matches the development objectives of the original credit.
            Therefore, no new development objectives are defined. The
            additional financing meets the demands of the recent
            Government minerals sector strategy and increased interest
            in technical assistance.

5085695.trustfund:
TF050618-PHRD-MADAGASCAR: SECOND MINING
            SECTOR REFORM PROJECT
5085695.majtheme: Public sector governance,Environment and natural resource management,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Mineral Resources Governance Project
            aims at strengthening governance and transparency in the
            management of mineral resources, placing particular emphasis
            on small-scale and artisanal mining. These objectives will
            be achieved through the project components, as follows.
            First, reforms in the mining sector's legal, and
            regulatory framework will be implemented, followed by
            support to the establishment of mining administration
            offices - close to exploitation sites, and establishment of
            a certification program for gemstones, with the aim to
            create a one-stop shop for gemstone exports, and exchange,
            with a specific focus on strengthening private sector
            associations. Second, institutional reforms for the
            decentralized management of mineral resources will be
            supported, as will communal efforts in extending access to
            cadastre information at the municipal level, streamlining
            tax collection, and the operations of the Directorate of
            Mines and Geology. An important aspect will be the training
            program, aimed at raising human resource capacity in the
            sector. Third, the Mining Sector Promotion Agency will be
            established, and the Geo-scientific Information
            Infrastructure strengthened through capacity building, to
            attract and promote private investments in the sector.
            Certification procedures, administration of a small grants
            program, and the establishment of geological/geophysical
            information databases will be coordinated, including the
            implementation of a geological/geo-chemical mapping to
            increase availability of mineral resources information.
            Finally, project management activities shall include project
            procurement, financial management, and reporting requirements.
